page.title: 17THE HARE PARK STUD YEAR
page.content: In the summer, the mares and foals live out in the paddocks both day and night. The stud manager keeps an eye on the mares that are foaling. He checks to see that there are no poisonous weeds, such as ragwort, growing in the paddocks and that the water supply is alright. In the winter, the horses are kept in big, roomy loose-boxes. They are fed in the morning on corn, mash and hay. Then the stables are mucked out. If the weather is fine and there is no snow or ice, the horses are turned out into the paddocks. In the late afternoon they are brought in and fed again. They spend all night in their loose-boxes.
